talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

item.para: 1 ) On 25 May 1 975 an explosion in shop premises operating as a trade and travel centre, situated at 154a Victoria Street, Seddon, Victoria, caused extensive damage to those premises and also damage to nearby premises.

The Centre was operated by Sunny Adriatic Trade and Travel Centre which is an independent firm with nominee directors in Yugoslavia, appointed by the Government of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

The explosion completely wrecked the interior of the premises at 1 54a Victoria Street and blew out the entire front of the shop, removing part of the roof. Structural and exterior damage to shops at 148, 150, 152, 154, 156 and 158 Victoria Street was caused. The Church Hall of Macedonian Orthodox Church of St Ilija at 83 Victoria Street sustained damage to its windows.

(a) Australian Police members in Victoria Region are assisting members of the Victoria Police Force in their inquiries to ascertain the origin of explosion and if any person was responsible for the damage caused. Australia Police are acting in liaison with Victoria Police in an effort to detect possible criminal offences and in order to determine if any breaches of the laws of Australia were involved. Because of (2) above there are possible matters of foreign affairs of interest to the Australian Government of obvious police significance. (b), (c) A Victoria Police Force spokesman is reported as informing the Press that, at that time, there was no evidence that there was political motive for the explosion.
Australia Police are continuing to assist the Victoria Police Force in their inquiries to ascertain the origin and cause of the explosion and if any person was or persons were responsible for it.
No prosecution has been commenced.
(a) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice:

item.para: With reference to the statement of the Minister that the Education Commissioners will be asked to review their triennial reports and to make recommendations by March 1976 for new triennial programs to commence in January 1975, what reason has been applied to this course of action and what instructions have now been given to the four Commissioners who have so recently presented comprehensive reports recommending triennial programs.
Does this course of action indicate a rejection and not a deferment of the recommended triennial programs.
Will the Minister make an early statement as a guide to the Governments and institutions involved in future planning of educational objectives.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Education has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's questions: (1), (2) and (3) The current general economic situation means we must defer the introduction of new triennial programs until 1977.

answer.para: Accordingly the Commissions have been asked to review their recent reports in the light of the 1975-76 situation and to make recommendations by March next. During the interim period to December 1976 we will continue the programs of the education Commissions and I expect soon to be able to announce details of these programs for the whole of 1976.

- On 4 June, Senator Marriott asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction the following question without notice:

quote.para: Is it a fact that the Department of Housing and Construction let a contract to a Victorian based firm for the installation of new electric generating equipment at the Hobart Airport on a tender which was $9,000 greater than that of a Hobart based contractor? Is the Minister able to inform the Senate of the reason for this discrimination against Tasmanian industry being permitted.

question.para: The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: On 22 February 1975 tenders were invited by public advertisement in Victoria and Tasmania for the supply, delivery, installation and testing of a Diesel Alternator Set of 150 k.w. capacity for Hobart Airport. Tenders closed on 18 March 1975 and five tenders were received. The lowest tender was $50,486 submitted by a firm in Hobart and the successful tender was priced at $59,537 submitted by Melbourne firm.

After receipt of all information required to be lodged with the tenders, the three lowest tenders were analysed and it was found that the two lowest tenders did not comply with specified requirements.
The lowest tenderer was advised in writing by the Department of Housing and Construction why its tender did not comply with the specification in respect of-

item.para: a ) engine power at specified maximum speed

item.label: (b)
item.para: generator output

item.label: (c)
item.para: governing characteristics

quote.para: All of the aspects mentioned in the advice to this company are critical in relation to the installation, as air safety is involved.

Although there is some marginal technical noncompliance in the governing characteristics of the accepted tender, it does comply strictly in the most important of the governing characteristics. The tender accepted is in fact an improvement on the specification in that the tenderer offered Automatic Voltage Regulators for the manual regulators specified.
